events.originalText: Twelve gunmen seized three buildings in Washington, D.C., and took 149 hostages in a 39-hour standoff that ended in two deaths.
events.subtitle: Washington, D.C.
events.headline: Twelve gunmen seize three buildings in Washington, D.C., taking 149 hostages

events.originalText: Svetlana Alliluyeva, the daughter of former Soviet leader Joseph Stalin, defected to the United States.
events.subtitle: Svetlana Alliluyeva
events.headline: Svetlana Alliluyeva defects to the United States

events.originalText: The popular fashion doll Barbie debuted at the American International Toy Fair in New York City.
events.subtitle: Barbie
events.headline: Barbie debuts at American International Toy Fair in New York City

events.originalText: The Mw 8.6 Andreanof Islands earthquake struck Hawaii and the Aleutian Islands, causing over $5 million in damage from ground movement and a destructive tsunami.
events.subtitle: 1957 Andreanof Islands earthquake
events.headline: Mw 8.6 Andreanof Islands earthquake causes $5 million in damage in Hawaii and Aleutian Islands

events.originalText: In Tbilisi, Georgia, Soviet military troops suppressed mass demonstrations against Soviet leader Nikita Khrushchev's de-Stalinization policy.
events.subtitle: Tbilisi
events.headline: Soviet troops suppress mass demonstrations in Tbilisi against de-Stalinization policy

events.originalText: Thirty-three people were killed in a human crush at Burnden Park, a football stadium in Bolton, England.
events.subtitle: Burnden Park disaster
events.headline: Thirty-three killed in human crush at Burnden Park football stadium in Bolton, England

events.originalText: World War II: In a coup d'état, Imperial Japanese Army officers ousted the government of French Indochina.
events.subtitle: World War II
events.headline: Imperial Japanese Army officers oust government of French Indochina in coup d'état

events.originalText: World War II: As part of the Battle of Narva, the Soviet Air Forces heavily bombed Tallinn, Estonia, killing up to 800 people, mostly civilians.
events.subtitle: World War II
events.headline: Soviet Air Forces bomb Tallinn, Estonia, killing up to 800 civilians

events.originalText: U.S. president Franklin D. Roosevelt submitted the Emergency Banking Act to the United States Congress, the first of his New Deal policies.
events.subtitle: Franklin D. Roosevelt
events.headline: Franklin D. Roosevelt submits Emergency Banking Act to Congress

events.originalText: Éamon de Valera (pictured), a dominant political figure in 20th-century Ireland, became President of the Executive Council of the Irish Free State.
events.subtitle: Éamon de Valera
events.headline: Éamon de Valera becomes President of the Executive Council of the Irish Free State

events.originalText: The Royal Air Force began a bombardment and strafing campaign against the mountain strongholds of Mahsud tribesmen in South Waziristan.
events.subtitle: Royal Air Force
events.headline: Royal Air Force begins bombardment campaign against Mahsud tribesmen in South Waziristan

events.originalText: A seventeen-month-long strike, which at its peak involved 15,000 coal miners represented by the United Mine Workers across 65 mines, began in Westmoreland County, Pennsylvania, U.S.
events.subtitle: Westmoreland County coal strike of 1910–1911
events.headline: Seventeen-month-long coal miners' strike begins in Westmoreland County, Pennsylvania

events.originalText: American Civil War: In the world's first battle between two ironclad warships, USS Monitor and CSS Virginia fought to a draw near the mouth of Hampton Roads in Virginia.
events.subtitle: American Civil War
events.headline: USS Monitor and CSS Virginia fight to a draw in world's first battle between ironclad warships

events.originalText: Mexican–American War: The Siege of Veracruz began, the first large-scale amphibious assault conducted by United States military forces.
events.subtitle: Mexican–American War
events.headline: Siege of Veracruz begins in Mexican–American War

events.originalText: Nabucco, an opera by Italian composer Giuseppe Verdi that established his reputation, premiered at La Scala in Milan.
events.subtitle: Nabucco
events.headline: Opera Nabucco by Giuseppe Verdi premieres at La Scala in Milan

events.originalText: The U.S. Supreme Court ruled that captive Africans who seized control of La Amistad, the trans-Atlantic slave-trading ship carrying them, had been taken into slavery illegally.
events.subtitle: Supreme Court of the United States
events.headline: U.S. Supreme Court rules captive Africans on La Amistad were taken into slavery illegally

events.originalText: Scottish political economist Adam Smith's book The Wealth of Nations, the first modern work in the field of economics, was first published.
events.subtitle: Adam Smith
events.headline: Adam Smith's The Wealth of Nations first published

events.originalText: The first recorded use of the name of Lithuania appeared in Latin in the Annals of Quedlinburg, written in Saxony-Anhalt, present-day Germany.
events.subtitle: Name of Lithuania
events.headline: First recorded use of name Lithuania appears in Annals of Quedlinburg
